repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - Innovations in Basic Education
            Project, the Second and Third NortheastBasic Education
            Projects, and the School Improvement Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the FUNDESCOLA project is
            rated satisfactory. The outcomes of the Innovations in Basic
            Education and Northeast Basic Education (NEBE) projects are
            rated moderately satisfactory. The projects exceeded or
            surpassed most targets for physical inputs and training but
            it is not clear that the learning goals were met. The
            objectives of the two NEBE projects were focused towards
            central management improvements, and these had little or no
            impact on quality improvement. Due to design shortcomings,
            Bank performance for the FUNDESCOLA project, which was
            designed to target schools, was satisfactory. Borrower
            performance is rated satisfactory for all but the
            Innovations in Education project. A number of OED lessons
            are confirmed with these projects: 1) Attention should be
            paid to state, municipal, or even school management, and
            moreover, to classromm time. States and municipalities that
            are better off are more likely to take advantage of
            Bank-financed resources. The challenge is to emcourage the
            poorer ones to benefit as well. Decentralizing school
            managmeent is not a panacea: autonomy permits the poorest or
            least knowledgeable municipalities to fall behind, without
            much possibility for helping the residents. Classroom
            observations may be used as predictors of achievement: they
            can potentially provide feedback and promote improvements
            sooner than achievement tests. Students' health needs
            and problems must be addressed to optimize cognitive
            development and classroom learning.

1960913.trustfund:
TF035276-BRAZIL - EDUCATION SECTOR,TF025482-PHRD -HUMAN CAPITAL DEVELOPMENT PORTFOLIO,TF027360-SCIENCE RESEARCG AND TRAINING PROJECT,TF027370-NORTHEAST BASIC EDUCATION,TF034238-BRAZIL - TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
            IN PROCUREMENT TRAINING AND REVIEW

abstracts.cdata!:
The assessment of outcome is
            satisfactory, sustainability likely, and institutional
            development impacts substantial. Lessons emphasize that
            working with state, and municipal governments (as these were
            directly responsible of the delivery of basic education), a
            recognition taken into account early on during project
            design, and implementation, ensured the political support,
            and demonstrated the efficacy of grassroots policies.
            Similarly, empowering schools through direct interventions,
            designed to generate greater school commitment to the
            project's development objectives, was conducive to
            success. This was demonstrated by an initial evaluation of
            the School Development Plan, which concluded that students
            under this plan performed better on assessment tests, and
            other dependent variables, such as student promotion rates.
            The popularity of these new educational development plans,
            presented the dilemma of expanding the project's
            success, though the project had reached its full training,
            and financial resources to bear. In response to this, the
            follow-up operation addresses expansion, with more explicit
            procedures, and criteria. The long-term strategy of an
            educational program (the project was prepared on previous
            project experiences, while lessons from this project will be
            incorporated to follow-up operations) allows for capacity
            building, technical skills, and innovations to flourish, and
            be institutionalized.

5085911.majtheme: Social protection and risk management,Urban development,Human development,Social dev/gender/inclusion

repnme.cdata!:
Brazil - School Improvement Project -
            FUNDESCOLA I

abstracts.cdata!:
The development objective of the School
            Improvement Project --FUNDESCOLA I-- for Brazil is to
            strengthen primary schools and the public institutions that
            are responsible for them within a coordinated management
            framework, in order to increase the participation, promotion
            and graduation rates, and achievement levels of children in
            the North and Center-West capital microregions of Brazil.
            There are four components. The first raises schools to
            minimum operational standards through educating and
            certifying teachers, supplying basic furniture and
            equipment, financing school improvement investments, and
            financing school-managed rehabilitation of physical
            facilities. The second component establishes a school
            development process by designing and supporting school
            development plans; and financing school subprojects. The
            third component carries out school microplanning and
            develops and tests standard architectural plans for
            additional school places. The fourth component builds
            management capacity in schools, municipalities, and states;
            provides specialized teaching and learning improvement
            programs; fosters community participation; strengthens
            national education information systems and programs; and
            finances project management.
